questions.stem: What is voluntary attendance?

options.text: A form of arrest
An alternative to arrest where a person attends the police station voluntarily for questioning
A type of bail
A court hearing

questions.explanation: Voluntary attendance is an alternative to arrest where a person attends the police station voluntarily for questioning. It is used when arrest is not necessary and the person is willing to attend. Voluntary attendees have certain rights but are not under arrest.

questions.stem: What rights does a voluntary attendee have?

options.text: No rights—they are not under arrest
Right to leave at any time (unless arrested), right to legal advice, and right to have someone informed
Only the right to legal advice
The same rights as someone under arrest

questions.explanation: Voluntary attendees have rights including: the right to leave at any time (unless they are then arrested), the right to legal advice, and the right to have someone informed. However, they are not under arrest, so detention time limits do not apply unless they are subsequently arrested.

questions.stem: When does a voluntary attendee become subject to arrest?

options.text: Never—voluntary attendance cannot become arrest
When arrest becomes necessary (e.g., they attempt to leave and there are grounds for arrest, or new information emerges requiring arrest)
Automatically after 24 hours
Only if they request it

questions.explanation: A voluntary attendee can be arrested if arrest becomes necessary. This might occur if: they attempt to leave and there are grounds for arrest, new information emerges requiring arrest, or circumstances change such that arrest is now necessary. The necessity test under s.24 PACE still applies.

questions.stem: What is a key difference between voluntary attendance and arrest?

options.text: There is no difference
Voluntary attendance does not trigger detention time limits; arrest does. Voluntary attendees can leave unless arrested; arrested persons cannot leave.
Only the method of arrival differs
Voluntary attendance requires bail conditions

questions.explanation: Key differences: (1) Detention time limits (s.41 PACE) apply to arrested persons but not to voluntary attendees (unless they are subsequently arrested). (2) Voluntary attendees can leave at any time unless arrested; arrested persons are in custody and cannot leave. (3) Voluntary attendance is an alternative to arrest when arrest is not necessary.
